content.text: A metre rule is attached at one end to the bench. The other end is supported by a forcemeter
A student records in Table 1.1 the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter

He places a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass on the rule at the \(50.0\mathrm{cm}\) mark and records in the table the value of the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter. He repeats the procedure using masses of \(200\mathrm{g}\) , \(300\mathrm{g}\) , \(400\mathrm{g}\) and \(500\mathrm{g}\) . The forcemeter readings are shown in the table
Write the mass values in the table
Plot a graph of \(F / \mathsf{N}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(m / \mathrm{g}\) ( \(x\) -axis)
Use the graph to find the value of \(F\) when \(m = 375 \text{g}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the result
The forcemeter shows a reading when no mass has been added to the metre rule. Assuming that the forcemeter has no zero error, suggest a reason for the reading
The IGCSE class is investigating the loading of a metre rule
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) as shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.2
Complete the time and temperature column headings in the table
Complete the time column in the table
A student pours hot water into the test-tube until it is about two thirds full of wa
places the thermometer in the water. When the thermometer reading stops rising,
measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the water and records \(\theta\) in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0\). S

starts a stopclock and records in the table the time \(t\) and the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30 s. She removes the thermometer and pours away the water from the test-tube. She then wraps cotton wool insulation round the test-tube and repeats the procedure
State in which experiment the cooling is more rapid. Justify your answer by reference to the readings
experiment
justification
If these experiments were to be repeated in order to check the results, it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two conditions that should be controlled
Suggest two alternative insulating materials that could be used in place of cotton wool
The IGCSE class is investigating the rate of cooling of water
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus
Calculate the values of resistance \(R\) for each length of wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). Enter the values in the table
Complete the column headings in the table

A student measures the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across the section of wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). He records the length \(l\) of the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). He repeats the procedure with the voltmeter connected across section \(\mathbf{AC}\) of the wire and then with the voltmeter connected across section \(\mathbf{AD}\) of the wire. The readings are shown in Table 3.1

It is suggested that the resistance across \(\mathbf{AB}\) should be half the resistance across \(\mathbf{AD}\). State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
It is known that changes in temperature affect the resistance of the wire. State how you can limit the temperature changes when carrying out this experiment
Draw the standard circuit symbol for a variable resistor
On Fig. 3.1, mark with an X a suitable position in the circuit for the variable resistor
The student wishes to use a lower current so he adds a variable resistor to the circuit
The IGCSE class is investigating the resistance of a wire
Fig. 3.1 shows the circuit

The student places a transparent block, largest face down, on a sheet of plain paper and draws the outline ABCD of the block. She removes the block and draws the normal NN' to side AB. She then draws the line EF at an angle of incidence \(i\)
On Fig. 4.1, measure the angle of incidence \(i\)
On Fig. 4.1, draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label this point \(\mathbf{H}\)
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line \(\mathbf{GH}\)
a =
Draw the line \(\mathbf{HF}\)
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line \(\mathbf{HF}\)
b =
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) of the material of the block using the equation \(n = \frac{b}{2a}\)
n =
She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\), as shown in Fig. 4.1, and replaces the
She observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the image

of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other. She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between the eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) , \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) , seen through the block, appear one behind the other
Suggest how far apart you would place the pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) if you were carrying out this experiment using a ray trace sheet the same size as this page
suggested distance =
Give a reason for your answer to (i)
reason

This experiment may be carried out using a ray of light, produced by a ray box, instead of by using optical pins. A student suggests that the ray box method will be more accurate. Assuming that the experiment is carried out with care, suggest one possible cause of inaccuracy using the optical pin method and one using the ray box method
optical pin method
ray box method
The IGCSE class is investigating the refraction of light through a transparent block
Fig. 4.1 shows a student's ray trace sheet. It is not drawn full size
An IGCSE student is investigating the relationship between the extension of
wire of unstretched length \(3.000 \text{m}\), and the load hung on the wire. He has a set of weights
Consider the readings that the student should take and write appropriate column headings, with units, in Table 5.1

The student decides to repeat the experiment using a wire made of a different metal in order to study how the extension may be affected by the metal from which the wire is made. To make a fair comparison, other variables must be kept constant. Suggest two variables that the student should keep constant
